freight.translation[0].definitions[0].de: goods that are carried by ship, train, or aircraft, and the system of moving these goods
freight.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Weâ€™ll send your personal belongings by air freight and your furniture by sea freight.
freight.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to send goods by air, sea, or train
freight.translation[2].definitions[0].de: goods carried in large quantities by ship, plane, train etc
freight.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: A 747 can carry freight as well as passengers.
The volume of rail freight is only 8% of the rail-and-road total.
The Panama Canal has lost some of its importance because of air freight.
The railroad is now only used by freight trains.
afreight car (=a wagon pulled by a train in which freight is carried)
freight.translation[2].definitions[1].de: the cost of carrying goods in large quantities by ship, plane, train etc
freight.translation[2].definitions[1].ex: The goods had been loaded on board the vessel and freight had been paid.
The railways adopted a negative attitude to the milk trade, refusing to grant concessionaryfreight rates.
freight.translation[2].definitions[2].de: used on the debit side of the profit and loss account to show that payments are for the cost of transporting goods a company has bought
freight.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to TRANSPORT goods in large quantities by ship, plane, train etc
freight.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: There was no time to send the equipment by ship, so it was freighted in a B747F aircraft.
